div.p: Lingua: OR THE COMBAT OF The Tongue, AND THE Five SENSES FOR SUPERIORITY. A pleasant Comoedy.
London, Printed for Simon Miller, at the Starre in St Pauls Church-yard. 1657.

div.head: LINGUA. DRAMMATIS Personae.

list.item:
VISUS.
LUMEN.
COELUM.
TERRA.
HERALDRY.
COLOR.

Personae quarum mentio tantum fit.
PSENCE.
ARCASIA.
VERITAS.
OELIVIO.

div.p: The Scene is MICROCOSMUS in a Grove.
The Time, from Morning till night.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: OUr Muse describes no Lovers passion,
No wretched Father, no unthrifty Son:
No craving subtile Whore, or shameless Bawd,
Nor stubborn Clown, or daring Parasite,
No lying Servant, or bold Sycophant.
We are not wanton, or Satyricall.
These have their time and places fit, but we
Sad hours, and serious studies, to reprive,
Have taught severe Phylosophy to smile.
The Senses rash contentions we compose,
And give displeas'd ambitious TONGUE her due:
Here's all Judicious friends; accept what is not ill,
Who are not such, let them do what they will.

stage.p: LINGUA, apparelled in a Crimson Sattin gown, a Dressing of white Roses, a little Skean tyed in a purple Skarf, a pair of red Buskins drawn with white Ribband, silk garters, gloves, &c.
AUDITUS, in a Garland of Bayes intermingled with red and white Roses upon a false hayr, a cloath of Silver Mantle upon a pair of Sattin Bases, wrought sleeves, Buskins, Gloves, &c.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: NAy good Auditus do but hear me speak.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.l: Lingua thou strik'st too much upon one string,
Thy tedious plain-song grates my tender ears.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: 'Tis plain indeed, for Truth no descant needs,
Una's her name, she cannot be divided.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.l: O but the ground it self is nought, from whence
Thou canst not relish out a good division:
Therefore at length surcease, prove not stark mad,
Hopelesse to prosecute a haplesse sute:
For though (perchance) thy first strains pleasing are,
I dare ingage mine ears, the cloze will jarre.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: If then your confidence esteem my cause,
To be so frivolous and weakly wrought:
Why do you daily subtile plots devise,
To stop me from the ears of common Sense,
Whom since our great Queen Psyche hath ordain'd,
For his sound wisdome, our Vice-governour,
To him, and to his two so wise assistants,
Nimble Phantastes, and firm Memorie:
My self and cause, I humbly do commit,
Let them but hear and judg, I wish no more,

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.l: Should they but know thy rash presumption,
They would correct it in the sharpest sort:
Good Jove what Sense hast thou to be a Sense;
Since from the first foundation of the world,
We never were accounted more then five;
Yet you forsooth, an idle prating Dame,
Would fain increase the number, and up-start
To our high seats, decking your babling self
With usurpt Titles of our dignity.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: An idle prating dame: know fond Auditus,
Records affirm my title full as good,
As his amongst the five is counted best.

sp.speaker: AUD
sp.l: Lingua confess the truth, th'art wont to lie,

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: I say so too, therefore I do not lye,
But now spite of you all I speak the truth.
You five among us subjects tyrannize,
Making the sacred name of common Sense,
A cloak to cover your enormities:
Hee bears the rule, hee's judg, but judgeth still,
As hee's informed by your false evidence:
So that a plaintiff cannot have access,
But through your gates he hears but what, nought els
But that thy crafty ears to him conveys,
And all he sees is by proud Visus shewed him:
And what he touches is by Tactus hand,
And smels I know but through Olfactus nose,
Gustus begins to him what ere he tastes:
By these quaint tricks free passage hath been barr'd
That I could never equally be heard.
But well, 'tis well.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.l: Lingua thy feeble sex,
Hath hitherto with-held my ready hands
That long'd to pluck that nimble instrument.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: O horrible ingratitude? that thou
That thou of all the rest should'st threaten me:
Who by my means conceiv'st as many tongues,
As Neptune closeth Lands betwixt his armes:
The ancient Hebrew clad with mysteres,
The learned Greek rich in fit Epithetes,
Blest in the lovely marriage of pure words,
The Chaldee Wise, the Arabian Physicall,
The Romane Eloquent, the Tuscane Grave,
The Braving Spanish, and the smooth tong'd French,
These pretious Iewels that adorn thine ears,
All from my mouthes rich Cabbinet are stolne,
How oft hast thou been chain'd unto my tongue,
Hang'd at my lips and ravisht with my words,
So that a speech fair fether'd could not flie:
But thy ears pit-fall caught it instantly,
But now O Heavens!

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.l: O Heavens, thou wrong'st me much,
Thou wrong'st me much thus falsly to upbraid me:
Had not I granted thee the use of hearing,
That sharp edg'd tongue whetted against her master,
Those puffing lungs, those teeth, those dropsie lips,
That scalding throat, those nosthrils full of ire:
Thy palate proper instruments of speech,
Like to the winged chanters of the wood,
Uttring nought else but idle stiflements,
Tunes without sense, words inarticulate:
Had ne're been able t'have abus'd me thus.
Words are thy Children, but of my begetting.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: Perfidious Liar, how can I endure thee?
Cal'st my unspotted chastity in Question:
O could I use the Breath mine anger spends,
I'de make thee know.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.l: Heaven look on my distresse,
Defend me from this railing viperesse:
For if I stay her words, sharp vinegar
Will fret me through, Lingua I must be gone:
I hear one call me more then earnestly. Exit Auditus.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: Nay the loud cannoning of thunder-bolts,
Screeking of Wolves, houling of tortur'd Ghosts,
Pursue thee still, and fill thy amazed ears
With cold astonishment and horrid fears:
O how these senses muffle common sense:
And more, and more with pleasing objects strive,
To dull his judgement, and pervert his will
To their be-hests, who were he not so wrapt
I' the dusky clouds of their dark policies,
Would never suffer right to suffer wrong:
Fie Lingua wilt thou now degenerate?
Art not a woman, dost not love revenge?
Delightfull speeches, sweet perswasions
I have this long time us'd to get my right,
My right that is to make the Senses six;
And have both name and power with the rest.
Oft have I seasoned savory periods,
With sugred words, to delude Gustus taste,
And oft embelisht my entreative phrase
With smelling flowers of vernant Rhetorique,
Limming and flashing it with various Dyes,
To draw proud Visus to me by the eyes:
And oft perfum'd my petitory style,
With Civet-speech, t' entrap Olfactus Nose,
And clad my self in Silken Eloquence,
To allure the nicer touch of Tactus hand,
But all's become lost labour, and my cause
Is still procrastinated; therefore now,
Hence ye base off-spring of a broken minde,
Supple intreaties and smooth flatteries:
Go kisse the love-sick lips of puling Guls,
That still their Brain to quench their loves disdain;
Go guild the tongues of Bawds and Parasites,
Come not within my thoughts; But thou Deceipt,
Break up the pleasure of my Brim-full brest,
Enrich my minde with subtile policies.
Well then Ile go, whither? nay, what know I?
And do, in faith I will, the devil knows what,
What if I set them all at variance,
And so obtein to speak, it must be so.
It must be so, but how? there lyes the point:
How? thust tut this device will never prove,
Augment it so, 'twill be too soon descri'd,
Or so, nor so 'tis too too dangerous.
Pish, none of these, what if I take this course? ha?
Why there it goes, good, good, most excellent.
He that will catch Eels must disturb the floud,
The Chicken's hatcht i'faith; for they are proud,
And soon will take a cause of disagreement.

div.head: ACTUS 1. SCENA. 2.
div.stage: MENDACIO, attired in a Taffata suit of a light colour changeable, like an ordinary Page, Gloves, Hamper.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: I see the heavens nurse my new-born device,
For loe my Page Mendacio comes already,
To file and burnish that I hammer'd out,
Never in better time Mendacio,
What? hast thou done?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Done, yes long agoe.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Is't possible? thou should'st dispatch so soon?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.l: Madame, I had no sooner told
Tactus, that Gustus would fain speak with him:
But I spied Visus, Gustus and the rest,
And served them all with sauce of severall lyes,
Now the last Sense I spake with was Olfactus,
Who having smelt the meaning of my message,
Straight blew his nose, and quickly puft me hither;
But in the whirl-winde of his furious blast,
Had not by chance a Cobweb held me fast,
Mendacio had been with you long ere this.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: Witness this lye, Mendacio's with me now,
But sirra out of jesting will they come?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: Yes and it like your Ladyship presently;
Here may you have me prest to flatter them.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: I'le flatter no such proud Companions.
'Twill do no good, therefore I am determined
To leave such baseness.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Then shall I turn and bid them stay at home.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: No, for their coming hither to this grove,
Shall be a means to further my device;
Therefore I pray thee Mendacio go presently,
Run you vile Ape.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: What? dost thou stand?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Till I know what to doe.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: S. pretious 'tis true,
So might thou finely out-run thine errand.
Hast to my Chest.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: I, I.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: There shalt thou find,
A gorgeous Robe, and golden Coronet,
Convey them hither nimbly, let none see them.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Madam, I fly, I fly.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: But here you sirra?
Lock up your fellow Servant, Veritas.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: I warrant you,
You need not fear, so long as I am with you.
sp.stage: He goes out, and comes in presently.
sp.l: What colour is the Robe?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: There is but one.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: The Key Madam, the Key.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: By Juno how forgetfull is sudden speed.
Here take it, Runne.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Ile be here instantly.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: Whilome this Crown and gorgious ornament,
Were the great prize, for which five Orators,
With the sharp weapons of their tongues contended:
But all their speeches were so equal wrought,
And a-like gracious, that if his were witty
His was as wise; the thirds fair eloquence
Did paralell the fourths firm gravity,
The lasts good gesture kept the Balance even
With all the rest, so that the sharpest eye,
And most judicious censor could not judge
To whom the hanging victory should fall,
Therefore with one consent they all agreed,
To offer up both Crown and Robe to me,
As the chief patronesse of their profession,
Which heretofore I holily have kept,
Like to a misers gold, to look on onely.
But now Ile put them to a better use,
And venture both in hope to—

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: Have not I hied me Madam? look you here,
What shall be done with these temptations?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: They say a golden Ball,
Bred enmity betwixt three Goddesses,
So shall this Crown be author of debate,
Betwixt five Senses.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Where shall it be laid?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: There, there, there, 'tis well, so, so, so.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: A Crown's a pleasing bait to look upon,
The craftiest Fox will hardly scape this trap.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Come let us away, & leave it to the chance.

sp.speaker: MEND
sp.l: Nay rather let me stand close here-abouts,
And see the event.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.l: Do so, and if they doubt
How it came there, fain them some pritty fable,
How that some God—

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: Tut, tut, tut, let me alone,
I that have fained so many hundred Gods,
Can easily forge some fable for the turn:
Whist Madame, away, away, you fright the Fowl,
Tactus comes hard by, look you,

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Is't he for certain?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: 'Tis he indeed

div.head: ACT. 1. SCEN. 5.
div.stage: TACTUS, in a dark coloured Sattin mantle over a pair of silk Basis, a Garland of Bayes mixt with white and red Roses, upon a black Grogram, a Faulchion, wrought sleeves, Buskins, &c.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Now chast Diana grant my Nets to hold!

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: The blasting Childhood of the cheerful morn
Is almost grown a youth and over-climbes
Yonder gilt Eastern hills, about which time,
Gustus most earnestly importuned me,
To meet him here abouts, what cause I know not.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: You shall do shortly to your cost I hope.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Sure by the Sunne it should be Nine a clock.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: What a Star-gazer, will you nere look down?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Cleer is the Sunne and blew the Firmament,
Me thinks the Heavens do smile.

sp.speaker: — MEN.
sp.l: At thy mishap.
To look so high and stumble in a trap.

div.stage: Tactus stumbleth at the Robe and Crown.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: High thoughts have slippry feet, I had well nie faln.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Well doth he fall that riseth with a fall.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: What's this!

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: O are you taken, 'tis in vain to strive.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: How now!

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: You'l be so entangled straight.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: A Crown!

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: That it will be heard.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: And a Robe!

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: To lose your self.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: A Crown and a Robe.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: It had been fitter for you, to have found a Fools Coate and a Bable, hey, hey.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: Jupiter, Jupiter how came this here?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: O Sir Jupiter is making Thunder, he hears you not, here's one knowes better.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.l: 'Tis wondrous rich, ha, but sure it is not so, ho,
Do I not sleep and dream of this good luck, ha?
No I am awake and feel it now
Whose should it be?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Set up a Si quis for it.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: Mercury, All's mine own, here's none to cry half's mine.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: When I am gone.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Tactus thy sneezing somewhat did portend,
Was ever man so fortunate as I?
To break his shinnes at such a stumbling Block.
Roses and Baies pack hence: this Crown and Robe,
My Brows and Body circles and invests.
How gallantly it fits me, sure the slave,
Measur'd my head that wrought this Coronet.
They lie that say Complexions cannot change:
My Blood's ennobled, and I am transform'd,
Unto the sacred temper of a King:
Methink I here my noble Parasites
Styling me Caesar, or great Alexander,
Licking my feet, and wondring where I got
This pretious oyntment: how my pace is mended,
How Princely do I speak, how sharp I threaten:
Peasants Ile curb your head-strong impudence:
And make you tremble when the Lion roars,
Yea earth-bred worms, O for a looking glasse:
Poets will write whole Volumes of this Change:
Where's my attendants? Come hither Sirra quickly,
Or by the wings of Hermes.—

div.head: ACT. 1. SCEN. 7.
div.stage: OLFACTUS, in a Garland of Bayes intermingled with white and red Roses upon a false hair, his sleeves wrought with flowers under a Damaskt mantle over a pair of silk Bases, a pair of Buskins drawn with riband, a flower in his hand.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Ay me Olfactus comes, I cal'd too soon,
Hee'l have half part I fear; what shall I do?
Where shall I run? how shall I shift him off?
sp.stage: Tactus wraps up the Robe and Crown, and sits upon them.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.l: This is the time and this the place appointed,
Where Visus promis'd to conferre with me.
I think he's there— No, no, 'tis Tactus sure.
How now? What makes you sit so nicely?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: It's past imagination, it's so indeed.

sp.speaker: OLF
sp.p: How fast his deeds are fixed, and how melancholly he looks. Tactus, Tactus.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: For this is true Mans life is wondrous brittle.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: He's mad I think, he talks so idlely, so ho, Tactus.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: And many have been metamorphosed,
To stranger matters and more uncouth forms.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: I must go nearer him, he doth not hear.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: And yet methinks, I speak as I was wont
And—

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: Tactus, Tactus.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Olfactus as thou lovest come not near me,

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: Why? art thou hatching eggs th'art feard to break them?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Touch me not lest thou chance to break my life.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: What's this under thee?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: If thou meddle with me I am utterly undone.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: Why man, what ayls thee?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Let me alone and Ile tell thee,
Lately I came from fine Fantastes house.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: So I beleeve for th'art very foolish.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: No sooner had I parted out of doors,
But up I held my hands before my face:
To shield mine eyes from th'lights piercing beams,
When I protest I saw the Sun as clear,
Through these my palms, as through a prospective:
No marvel, for when I beheld my fingers,
I saw my fingers near transform'd to glasse,
Opening my Breast, my Breast was like a window,
Through which I plainly did perceive my heart:
In whose two Concaves I discern'd my thoughts,
Confus'ly lodged in great multitudes.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, why this is excellent,
Momus himself can find no fault with thee,
Thou'st make a passing live Anatomy.
And decide the Question much disputed,
Betwixt the Galenists and Aristotle.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: But when I had ariv'd and set me down,
Viewing my self, my self ay me was changed.
As thou now seest to a perfect Urinal.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: T'a perfect Urinal, O monstrous, monstrous, art not mad to think so?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: I do not think so, but I say I am so;
Therefore Olfactus come not near I advise you.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.l: See the strange working of dull melancholly;
Whose drossie drying the feeble Brain,
Corrupts the sense, deludes the Intellect.
And in the souls fair table falsly graves,
Whole squadrons of phantastical Chimera's,
And thousand vain imaginations:
Making some think their heads as big as horses,
Some that th'ar dead, some that th'ar turnd to Wolves:
As now it makes him think himself all glasse,
Tactus disswade thy self, thou dost but think so.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Olfactus if thou lovest me get thee gone,
I am an Urinal I dare not stirre,
For fear of cracking in the Bottome.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: Wilt thou sit thus all day?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Unlesse thou help me.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: Bedlam must help thee, what wouldst have me do?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Go to the City make a Case fit for me:
Stuff it with wool, then come again and fetch.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, thou'lt be laught out of case and countenance.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: I care not, so it must be, or I cannot stirre.

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p:
I had best leave troubling him, he's obstinate, (Urinal I leave you) but above all things take heed Jupiter sees you not, for if he do, he'l nere make
water in sive again; thou'lt serve his turn so fit to carry his water unto Aesculapius, Farewell Urinal, Farewell.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Speak not so lowd, the sound's enough to crack me, What is he gone? I an Urinal, ha, ha, ha, I protest I might have had my face washt finely, if he had meant to abuse me: I an Urinal, ha, ha, ha, go to, Urinal you have scapt a fair scouring, well Ile away, and get me to mine own house, there Ile lock up my self fast, playing the Chimick, augmenting this one Crown to troops of Angels, with which gold-winged messengers, I mean,
sp.l: To work great wonders, as to build and purchase,
Fare daintily, tie up mens tongues, and loose them,
Command their lives, their goods, their liberties,
And captive all the world with chains of gold:
Hey, hey, tery linkum tinkum.
sp.stage: He offers to go out, but comes in suddenly amazed.
sp.l: O Hercules!
Fortune the Queen delights to play with me,
Stopping my passage with the sight of Visus;
But as he makes hither, Ile make hence,
There's more waies to the wood than one.
sp.stage: He offers to go out at the other door, but returns again in hast.
sp.l: What more Devils to affright me?
O Diabolo, Gustus comes here to vex me:
So that I poor wretch, am like a Shittle-cock betwixt two Battledoors, If I run there, Visus beats me to Scilla, If here, then Gustus blows me to Carybdis.
Neptune hath sworn my hope shall suffer shipwrack..
What shall I say?
Mine Urinal's too thin to bide the fury of such storms as these.

stage.p: VISUS, in a Garland of Bays, mixt with white and red Roses, a light coloured Taffata mantle striped with silver, and fring'd upon green silk Bases, Buskins, &c.
GUSTUS, in the same fashion, differing only in colour.
TACTUS, in a corner of the Stage.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Gustus good day.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.l: I cannot have a bad,
Meeting so fair an omen as your self.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Shall I? wilt prove? ha? well 'tis best to venture.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: Saw you not Tactus, I should speak with him.

sp.speaker: TACT
sp.p: Perchance so, a sudden lie hath best luck.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: That face is his, or else mine eye's deceiv'd,
Why how now Tactus, what so gorgious?

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: Where didst thou get these fair habiliments?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Stand back I charge you as you love your lives,
By Stix, the first that toucheth me shall die.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: I can discern no weapons, will he kill us?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Kill you? not I, but come not neer me you had best.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Why, art thou mad?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: Friends as you love your lives,
Venture not once to come within my reach.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: Why dost threaten so?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: I do not threaten, but in pure love advise you for the best,
Dare not to touch me, but hence fly apace,
Adde wings unto your feet and save your lives.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Why what's the matter Tactus prethe tell me?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: If you will needs jeopard your lives so long,
As hear the ground of my amazednesse,
Then for your better safety stand aside.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.l: How full of ceremonies, sure he'l conjure,
For such like Robes Magicians use to wear.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: Ile see the end, though he should unlock Hell:
And set th'infernall haggs at liberty.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: How rash is man on hidden arms to rush!
It was my chance, O chance most miserable!
To walk that way that to Crumena leads.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: You mean Cremona a little Town hard by.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: I say Crumena, called Vacua,
A Town which doth, and alwaies hath belong'd,
Chiefly to Scholars: from Crumena wals,
I saw a man came stealing craftily,
Apparelled in this vesture which I wear,
But seeing me eft-soons, he took his heels,
And threw his garment from him all in hast,
Which I perceiving to be richly wrought,
Took it me up: But good now get you gone,
Warn'd by my harms, and scape my misery.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: I know no danger, leave these circumstances.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.l: No sooner had I put it on my back,
But suddenly mine eyes began to dim,
My joynts wax sore, and all my body burn
With most intestine torture, and at length,
It was too evident, I had caught the plague.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: The plague, away good Gustus lets be gone,
I doubt 'tis true, now I remember me,
Crumena Vacua never wants the plague.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: Tactus Ile put my self in jeopardy to pleasure thee.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: No gentle Gustus, your absence is the only thing I wish,
Lest I infect you with my company.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: Farewell. Exit Gustus.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: I willingly would stay to do thee good.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: A thousand thanks, but since I needs must die,
Let it suffice, death only murthers me,
Oh 'twould augment the dolour of my death,
To know my self the most unhappy Bow,
Through which pale death should aim his shafts at you.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: Tactus farewell, yet die with this good hope,
Thy corps shall be interred as they ought. Exit Visus.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.l: Go make my Tomb, provide my funerals, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha,
Excellent Asses thus to be deluded,
Bewail his death and cruel destinies,
That lives, and laughs your fooleries to scorn,
But where's my Crown, oh here: I well deserve,
Thus to be crowned for two great victories, ha, ha, ha,
Visus take care my corps be well interr'd:
Go make my Tomb, and write upon the Stone;
Here lies the Sense, that lying gul'd them all,
With a false plague, and fained Urinal.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: Tactus, Tactus

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: O Jupiter, 'tis Auditus, all's mard, I doubt the slie knave hears so far, but yet Ile grope him: how now Ears, what make you here, ha?

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: Nay, what make you here, I pray what were you talking even now, of an Asse, and a Crown, and an Urinal, and a plague?

sp.speaker: TA.
sp.p: A plague on you, what I?

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: Oh, what you.

sp.speaker: TA
sp.p: O I had well nigh forgot nothing, but I say—

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: That if a man (do you mark sir) being sick of the plague (do you see sir) had a, a, a, hem, hem, (this cold troubles me, It makes me cough sometimes extreamly,) had a French Crown, (sir you understand me) lying by him, and (come hither, come hither) and would not bestow two pence (do you hear) to buy an Urinal (do you mark me) to carry his water to the Physician, (hem)

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: What of all this?

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p:
I say such a one was a very Asse, this was all I use to speak to my self, when I am alone; but Auditus, when shall we hear a new set of singing
books, or th'viols, or the consort of Instruments.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: This was not all, for I heard mention of a Tomb, and an Epitaph.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: True, true, I made my self merry with this Epitaph, upon such a fools Tomb thus a, thus, thus, plague brought this man, (foh I have forgotten) O thus, plague brought this man (so, so, so) unto his burial, because, because, because, (hem, hem) because he would not buy an Urinal, come, come Auditus, shall we hear thee play, the Lyroway, or the Lute-way shall we, or the Cornet, or any Musick, I am greatly revived when I hear.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: Tactus, Tactus, this will not serve, I heard all, you have not found a Crown: you, no, you have not.

div.head: ACT. 1. SCEN. Ultima.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Peace, peace, faith peace, come hither, hark thee good now.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: I cannot hold I must needs tell.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: O do not, do not, do not, come hither, will you be a fool?

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Had he not wings upon his feet and shoulders?

sp.speaker: MEN
sp.l: Yes, yes, and a fine wand in his hand,
Coriously wrapped with a pair of snakes.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Will half content you, pish 'twill nere be known.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: My life, 'twas Mercury.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: I do not know his name, but this I am sure his hat had wings upon't.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Doubtles 'twas he, but say my Boy what did he?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: First I beheld him hovering in the air,
And then down stooping with a hundred gires:
His feet he fixed on Mount Chephalon,
From whence he flew and lighted on that plain,
And with disdainfull steps soon glided thither:
Whither arived, he suddenly unfolds
A gorgeous Robe, and glittering ornament,
And lays them all, upon that hillock:
This done he wafts his wand, took wing again,
And in a moment vanisht out of sight,
With that mine eies 'gan stare, and heart grew cold,
And all my quivering joynts with sweat bedew'd:
My heels my thought had wings as well as his,
And so away I runne; but by the way,
I met a man as I thought coming thither,

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: What marks had he?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: He had a great— what this is he, this is he:

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: What Tactus?

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: This was the plague vext him so, Tactus your Grave gapes for you, are you ready?

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: Since you must needs die, do as others do,
Leave all your goods behinde you; bequeath the
Crown and Robe to your Executors.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.l: No such matter, I like the Egyptian Knights,
For the more state, will be buried in them.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Come, come, deliver:

div.stage: Visus snatcheth the Crown and sees letters graven in it.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: What will you take my purse from me?

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: No but a Crown, that's just more then your own.
Ha, what's this? 'tis a very smal hand,
What Inscription is this?
He of the five that proves himself the best,
Shall have his Temples with this Coronet blest.
This Crown is mine, and mine this garment is,
For I have alwaies been accounted best.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Next after me, I as your self at any time: besides I found it first, therefore 'tis mine.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: Neither of yours but mine as much as both.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: And mine the most of any of you all.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Give me it or else—

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Ile make you late repent it———

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.p: Presumptuous as you are———

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: Spite of your teeth——

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: Never till now, a ha, it works apace,
Visus I know tis yours, and yet methinks,
Auditus you should have some challenge to it,
But that your title Tactus is so good:
Gustus I would swear the Coronet were yours,
What will you all go braule about a trifle:
View but the pleasant coast of Microcosm,
Ist not great pity to be rent with warres,
Ist not a shame, to stain with brinish tears,
The smiling cheeks of ever-cheerfull peace,
Ist not farre better to live quietly,
Than broyl in fury of dissention;
Give me the Crown, ye shall not disagree,
If I can please you; Ile play Paris part,
And most unpartial judge the controversie:

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Sauce-box go meddle with your Ladies fanne, and prate not here.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: I speak not for my self, but for my Countries safe commodity.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Sirra be still.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: Nay and you be so hot, the devil part you,
Ile to Olfactus and send him amongst you.
O that I were Alecto for your sakes:
How liberally would I bestow my snakes.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: Tactus upon thine honour,
I challenge thee to meet me here,
Strong as thou canst provide in th'afternoon.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.l: I undertake the Challenge, and here's my hand,
In sign thou shalt be answered.

sp.speaker: GUST.
sp.l: Tactus Ile joyn with thee, on this condition,
That if we win, he that fought best of us,
Shall have the Crown, the other wear the Robe.

sp.speaker: TACT.
sp.p: Give me your hand, I like the motion.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.l: Auditus shall we make our forces double,
Upon the same terms.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: Very willingly:

sp.speaker: VIS
sp.l: Come lets away, fear not the victory.
Right's more advantage, than an host of souldiers.

div.head: Actus 2. Scena 1.
div.stage: APPETITUS, A long lean Raw-bon'd fellow in a Souldiers coat, a sword, &c.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: I long to see those hot-spur senses at it, they say they have gallant preparations, and not unlikely, for most of the souldiers are ready in Arms since the last field fought against their yearly enemy Meleager, and his wife Acrasia; that Conquest hath so flesht them, that no peace can hold them. But had not Meleager been sick, and Acrasia drunk, the senses might have whistled for the victory.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Foh, what a stink of gunpowder is yonder?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Who's this! oh, oh, 'tis Appetitus, Gustus his hungry Parasite.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: I cannot indure the smoking of Gunnes, the thundring of drums, I had rather hear the merry hacking of pot-herbs, and see the reaking of a hot Capon. If they would use no other Bucklers in warre, but shields of Brawn, brandish no swords but sweards of Bacon, trail no spears, but sparribs of Pork, and instead of Harquebuss pieces discharge Hartichockpies, tosse no pikes but boyled Pickrels, then Appetitus would rouse up his crest, and bear up himself with the proudest.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Ah here's a youth stark naught at a trench but old dog at a trencher, a tall squire at a square table

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: But now my good masters must pardon me I am not for their service, for their service is without service, and indeed their service is too hoat for my diet. But what, If I be not my self, but only this be my spirit that wanders up and down, and Appetitus be killed in the Camp, the Devil he is as soon, how's that possible? tut, tut, I know I am, I, I am Appetitus, and alive too, by this Infallible token, that I feel my self hungry.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Thou might'st have taken a better token of thy self, by knowing thou art a fool.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Well then, though I made my fellow souldiers admire the beauty of my back, and wonder at the nimblenesse of my heels, yet now will I at safety at home, tell in what dangers they are abroad, Ile speak nothing but guns, and glaves, and staves, and phalanges, and squadrons, and barracadoes, ambuscadoes, palmedoes blank point dept, counterpoint, counterscraf, sallies, and lies, saladoes, tarantantaras, ranta, tara, tara, hey.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: I must take the fife out of his mouth, or he'l nere adone.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: But above all Ile be sure on my knees to thank the great—

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Who am I, who am I, who I?

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: By the bloud-stain'd fauchion of Mauors— I am on your side

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Why, who am I?

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Are you a souldier?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Then you are master Helluo the Bear-ward,

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: No, no, he's dead.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Or Gulono the gutty Serjeant, or Delphino the Vintner, or else I know you not, for these are all my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Would I were hang'd, if I be any of these,

sp.speaker: APP
sp.p: What Mendacio, by the faith of a Knight thou art welcome, I must borrow thy Whetstone to sharpen the edges of my martial complements.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: By the faith of a Knight, what a pox, where are thy Spurres?

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: I need no spurres, I ride like Pegasus on a winged horse, on a swift Gennet, my Boy, called fear.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: What should'st thou fear in the wars? he's not a good souldier that hath not a good stomack.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: O, but the stink of powder spoils Appetitus stomack, and then thou know'st when 'tis gone, Appetitus is dead, therefore I very manfully drew my sword, and flourisht it bravely about mine ears, kist, and finding my self hurt, most manfully run away.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: All heart indeed, for thou ran'st like a Hart out of the field:
It seems then the Senses mean to fight it out.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: I, and out-fight themselves I think, and all about a trifle, a paltry bable, found I know not where.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p:
Thou art deceived, they fight for more then
that, a thing called Superiority, of which the Crown is but an Embleme.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Mendacio hang this Superiority, Crown me no Crown but Bacchus Crown of Roses, give me no Scepter, but a far (apons legge, to shew that I am the great King of Hungary, therefore I prethee talk no more of State-matters, but in brief, tell me my little rascall, how thou hast spent thy time this many a day?

sp.speaker: MEN
sp.p: Faith in some credit since thou saw'st me last.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: How so, where?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Every where; in the Court your Gentlewomen hang me at their Apron strings, and that makes them answer so readily. In the City I am honour'd like a God, none so well acquainted with your Tradesmen: your Lawyers all the Term time hire me of my Lady, your Gallants if they hear my name abused, they stab for my sake: your Travellers so dote upon me as passes, O they have good reason, for I have carried them to many a good meal, under the Countenance of my familiarity: Nay your States-men have oftentimes closely conveyed me under their tongues, to make their policies more currant: As for old men they challenge my Company by authority.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: I am exceeding glad of your great promotion.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Now when I am disposed, I can Philophy it in the University, with the subtilest of them all.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: I cannot be perswaded that th'art acquainted with Scholars ever since thou wert prest to death in a Print-house.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: No, why I was the first founder of the three sects of Phylosophy, except one of the Peripateticks who acknowledge Aristotle (I confess) their great Grand-father.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Thou Boy, how is this possible? thou art but a Child and there were sects of Philosophy before thou wert born.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Appetitus, thou mistakest me, I tell thee, 3000 years ago was Mendacio born in Greece, nurst in Creete, and ever since honoured every where: Ile be sworn I held old Homers pen when he writ his Iliads and his Odysses.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Thou hadst need, for I hear say he was blind.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: I helped Herodotus to pen some part of his Muses, lent Pliny ink to write his History, rounded Rabalais in the ear when he historified Pantagruell; as for Lucian, I was his Genius, O those two Books De Vera Historia, howsoever they go under his Name, Ile be sworn I write them every tittle.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Sure as I am Hungry, thou'st have it for lying. But hast thou rusted this later time for want of exercise?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p:
Nothing lesse, I must confesse I would fain have jogged Stow and great Hollinshead on
their elbows, when they were about their Chronicles, and as I remember Sir John Mandevils Travels, and a great part of the Decads were of my doing. But for the mirror of Knight-hood, Bevis of Southampton, Palmerin of England, Amadis of Gaule, Huon de Burdeaux, Sir Guy of Warwick, Martin mar-prelate, Robin-hood, Garragantua, Gevilion, and a thousand such exquisite monuments as these, no doubt but they breathe on my breath up and down.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Downwards Ile swear, for there's stinking lies in them.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: But what should I light a Candle to the bright Sunne shine of my glorious renown, the whole world is full of Mendacios fame.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: And so it will be so long as the world is full of fame.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: But Sirra, how hast thou done this long time?

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: In as much request as thy self. To begin with the Court, as thou didst, I lie with the Ladies all night, and that's the reason they call for Cullies, and Gruellies so early before their prayers, your Gallants never sup, break-fast or beaver without me.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: That's false, for I have seen them eat with a full stomack.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p:
True, but because they know a little thing drives me from them, therefore in midst of meat they present me with some sharp sauce or a dish of
delicate Anchoves, or a Caviare, to entice me back again; nay more, your old Sirs that hardly go without a prop, will walk a mile or two every day to renew their acquaintance with me, as for the Academy, it is beholding to me for adding the eighth province unto noble Heptarchy of the liberall sciences.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: What's that I prethee.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.l: The most desired and honourable art of Cookery.
Now Sirra in the City I am— st, st.
O the body of a Louse.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: What art a louse in the City?

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Not a word more, for yonder comes Phantastes, and some body else.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: What a pox can Phantastes do?

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Work a miracle if he would prove wise.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: 'Tis he indeed, the vilest nup: yet the fool loves me exceedingly, but I care not for his company, for if he once catch me, I shall never be rid of him.

stage.p:
PHANTASTES, A swart complexion'd fellow, but quick ey'd, in a white Sattin doublet of one fashion, green velvet hose of another: A phantasticall has with a plume of fethers of several colours, a little short taffaty cloak, a pair of Buskins cut, drawn
out with sundry coloured Ribands, with scarfs hung about him, after all fashions, and of all colours, rings, Jewels, a Fanne, and in every place other odd complements.
HEURESIS, A nimble sprighted page in the newest fashion, with a garland of Bayes, &c.

sp.speaker: PHAN.
sp.p: Sirra Boy Heuresis? boy how now biting your nails?

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Three things have troubled my brain this many a day, and just now, when I was laying hold on the Invention of them, your sudden call, made them like Tantalus apples, fly from my fingers.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Some great matters questionless, what were they?

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: The quadrature of a circle, the Philosophers stone, and the next way to the Indies.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Thou dost well to meditate on these three things at once, for they'l be found out altogether, ad gracas calendas, but let them passe, and carry the conceit I told you this morning, to the party you wot of. In my imagination 'tis Capritious, 'twill take I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: I will Sir: But what say you to the Gentleman that was with you yesterday?

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: O I think thou meanest him that made nineteen sonnets of his Mistress Busk-point:

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: The same, the same, Sir: You promis'd to help him out with th' twentieth.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: By Jupiters cloven pate 'tis true; but we witty fellows are so forgetfull, but stay, hu, hu, carry him this:

lg.l: The gordian knot which Alexander great,
Did whilom cut with his all conquering sword:
Was nothing like thy Busk-point pretty Peate,
Nor could so fair an augury afford.

sp.p: Then to conclude let him pervert Catullus his zonam solvit diù ligatam, thus, thus,

lg.l: Which if I chance to cut or else unty,
Thy little world Ile conquer presently.

sp.p: 'Tis pretty, pretty, tell him 'twas extemporal.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Well Sir, but now for Master Inamorato's Love-letter.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Some netling stuffy faith; let him write thus: Most heart commanding fac't Gentlewoman, even as the stone in India called Basiliscus, hurts all that looks on it: and as the Serpent in Arabia called Smaragdus, delighteth the sight, so does thy celestial orb assimilating eyes, both please, and in pleasing wound my Love-darted heart.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: But what trick shall I invent for the conclusion?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Pish, any thing: Love will minister Ink for the rest:
He that once begun well, hath half done, let him begin again, and there's all.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Master Gullio spoke for a new fashion, What for him?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: A fashion for his sute— let him button it down the sleeve with four elbows, and so make it the pure heiroglyphick of a fool.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Nay then let me request one thing of you.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: What's that Boy? by this fair hand thou shalt have it.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Mistresse Superbia a Gentlewoman of my acquaintance wisht me to devise her a new set for her Ruff, and an odde tire, I pray Sir, help me out with it.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Ah Boy in my conceit it's a hard matter to perform, these women have well nigh tired me, with devising tires for them, and set me at a non plus for new sets, their heads are so light, and their eyes so coy, that I know not how to please them.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: I pray Sir, she hath a bad face, and fain would have Sutors, Phantastical and odd apparel, would perchance draw some body to look on her.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: If her face be nought, in my opinion, the more view it, the worse, bid her wear the multitude of her deformities under a Mask, till my leasure will serve to devise some durable, and unstained blush of painting.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Very good Sir.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Away then, hye thee again, meet me at the Court within this hour at the farthest.

Oh heavens, how have I been troubled these later
times with Women, Fools, Babes, Taylers, Poets, Swaggerers, Guls, Ballad-makers, they have almost disrobed me of all the toys and trifles I can devise; were it not that I pity the poor multitude of Printers, these Sonnet-mongers should starve for conceits, for all Phantastes. But these puling Lovers, I cannot but laugh at them and their Encomions of their Mistresses. They make forsooth her hair of Gold, her eyes of Diamond, her cheeks of Roses, her lips of Rubies, her teeth of Pearl, and her whole body of Ivory: and when they have thus Idol'd her like Pigmalion, they fall down and worship her. Psyche, thou hast laid a hard task upon my shoulders, to invent at every ones ask, were it not that I refresh my dulnesse once a day with my most Angelical presence, 'twere unpossible for me to undergo it.

div.head: ACTUS 2 SCENA 3.
div.stage: COMMUNIS SENSUS, A grave man in a Black velvet Cassock like a Councellor, speaks coming out of the door.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: I cannot stay, I tell you 'tis more then time I were at Court, I know my Sovereign Psyche hath expected me this hour.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p:
In good time, younder comes Common-sense,
I imagine it should be he by his voice.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Crave my counsell, tell me what manner of man he is? Can he entertain a man into his house, can he hold his Velvet Cap in one hand, and vale his bonnet with the other? Knows he how to become a Scarlet gown, hath he a pair of fresh posts at his door?

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: He's about some hasty State-matters, he talks of posts methinks.

sp.speaker: COM S.
sp.p: Can he part a couple of Dogs brawling in the street? why then choose him Mayor, upon my credit he'l prove a wise Officer.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Save you my Lord, I have attended your leisure this hour.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Fie upon't, what a toil have I had to choose them a Mayor yonder? there's a fusty Currier will have this man: there's a Chandler wipes his nose on his sleeve, and swears it shall not be so. There's a Mustard-maker looks as keen as Viniger, will have another: O this many headed multitude, it's a hard matter to please them!

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Especially where the multitude is so well headed. But I pray you where's Master Memory? hath he forgotten himself that he is not here?

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: 'Tis high time he were at Court, I would he would come.

stage.p: MEMORY, An old decrepit man, in a black Velvet Cassock, a Taffaty Gown furred, with white Grogram, a white beard, Velvet slippers, a Watch, Staff, &c.

ANAMNESTES his Page, in a grave Sattin sute Purple, Buskins, a Garland of Bayes and Rosemary, a gimmall ring, with one link hanging, Ribbands and Threds tied to some of his fingers, in his hand a pair of Table books, &c.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: How soon a wise man shall have his wish?

sp.speaker: COM. SE.
sp.p: Memory the season of your coming is very ripe.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Had you staid a little longer 'twould have been stark rotten.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I am glad I sav'd it from the Swine— Spretious I have forgot something: O my purse, my purse, why Anamnestes? Remembrance where art thou, Anamnestes Remembrance, that vild Boy is alwaies gadding, I remember he was at my heels, even now, and now the vild Rascal is vanisht.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Is he not here? why then in my imagination he's left behind, O la Anamnestes remembrance.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: (running in hast )Anon, anon, sir anon, anon sir, anon, anon sir, anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Ha sirra, what a brawling's here?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: I do but give you an answer with anon Sir.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: You answer sweetly, I have cal'd you three or four times one after another.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: Sir, I hope I answered you three or four times one in the neck of another. But if your good worship have lent me any more cals, tell me, and Ile repay them as I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Leave your tattle, had you come at first I had not spent so much breath in vain.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: The truth is Sir, the first time you called, I heard you not, the second I understood you not, the third I knew not whether it were you or no: the fourth I could not tell where you were, and that's the reason I answered so suddenly.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Go sirra, run, seek every where, I have lost my purse somewhere.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: I go Sir: Go sirra, seek, run, I have lost, bring, here's a Dogs life, with a pox, shall I be alwaies used like a water-Spaniel.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: Come good Master Register, I wonder you be so late now adaies.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: My good Lord, I remember that I knew your Grandfather in this your place, and I remember your Grandfathers great Grandfathers, Grandfathers Fathers, Father, yet in those daies I never remember that any of them could say, that Register Memory ever broke one minute of his appointment.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Why good Father, why are you so late now adaies?

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Thus 'tis, the most customers I remember my self to have, are (as your Lordship knows) Scholars, and now adaies the most of them are become Criticks, bringing me home such paltry things to lay up for them, that I can hardly find them again.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Jupiter, Jupiter, I had thought these Flies had bit none but my self, Do Criticks tickle you yfaith?

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Very familiarly: for they must know of me forsooth, how every idle word is written in all the musty moth-eaten Manuscripts, kept in all the old Libraries in every City betwixt England and Peru.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Indeed I have noted these times to affect Antiquities more than is requisite.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I remember in the age of Assaracus and Ninus, and about the warres of Thebes, and the siege of Troy, there was few things committed to my charge, but those that were well worthy the preserving, but now every trifle must be wrapped up in the volume of Eternity. A rich pudding-wife, or a Cobler cannot die but I must immortalize his Name with an Epitaph: A dog cannot pisse in a Noblemans shoe, but it must be sprinkled into the Chronicles, so that I never could remember my Treasure more full, and never emptier of Honourable, and true Heroicall actions.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p:
By your leave Memory, you are not alone troubled, Chronologers many of them are so Phantastick, as when they bring a Captain to the Combat, lifting up his revengefull arm to dis-part the head of
his enemy, they'l hold up his arms so long till they have bestowed three or four pages in describing the gold hilts of his threatning Fauchion: So that in my Fancy the Reader may well wonder his adversary stabs him not before he strikes; moreover they are become most palpable flatterers, alwaies begging at my gates for Invention.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: This is a great fault in a Chronologer to turn Parasite: An absolute History should be in fear of none, neither should he write any thing more then truth for friendship, or less for hate, but keep himself equal and constant in all his discourses, but for us, we must be contented, for as our Honours increase, so must the burthen of the cares of our Offices urge us to wax heavy.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: But not till our backs break, s'lud there was never any so haunted as I am, this day there comes a Sophister to my house, knocks at my door, his errand being ask'd forsooth his answer was, to borrow a fair sute of conceits out of my wardrobe, to apparell, a shew he had in hand, and what think you is the plot?

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: Nay I know not, for I am little acquainted with such toies.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Mean-while he's somewhat acquainted with you, for he's bold to bring your person upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: What me? I cannot remember, that I was ever brought upon the Stage before.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Yes you and you, and my self, with all my Phantasticall tricks and humors, but I trow I have fitted him with Fooleries, I trust he'l never trouble me again.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: O times! O manners! when Boyes dare to traduce men in authority, was ever such an attempt heard!

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I remember there was For (to say the truth) at my last being at Athens (It is now, let me see, about 1800 years ago) I was at a Comedy of Aristophanes making, (I shall never forget it) The Arch-governour of Athens took me by the hand and placed me, and there I say, I saw Socrates abused most grosly, himself being then a present spectator: I remember he sate full against me, and did not so much as shew the least countenance of discontent.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: In those daies it was lawfull, but now the abuse of such liberty is unsufferable.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Think what you will of it, I think 'tis done, and I think it is acting by this time; hark, hark, what drumming's yonder, Ile lay my life they are come to present the shew I spake of.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: It may be so; stay we'l see what 'tis.

div.head: ACT. 2. SCEN. 5.
div.stage: LINGUA. MENDACIO. COM. SEN. and the rest.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Fain thy self in great haste.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: I warrant you Madam: I doubt 'tis in vain to run, by this they are all past overtaking.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Is not this Lingua that is in such hast?

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Yes, yes, stand still.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: I must speak with him.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Assure your self they are all at Court ere this.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Run after them, for unlesse he know it—

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Lingua.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: O ist your Lordship: I beseech you pardon me; hast and fear, I protest put out mine eyes: I lookt so long for you, that I knew not when I had found you.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: In my conceit, that's like the man that enquired, who saw his Asse, when himself rid on him.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: O my heart beats so, fie, fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: I am so weary, fo, fo, fo, fo.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: I prethee Lingua make an end.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Let me begin first I beseech you, but if you will needs have the end first, thus 'tis. The Commonwealth of Microsme at this instant suffers the pangs of death, 'tis gasping for breath. Will you have all? 'tis poysned.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: What Pothecary durst be so bold as make such a confection? ha what poyson ist?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: A golden Crown.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: I mistake, or else Galen in his Book De sanitate tuenda, commends gold as restorative.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Lingua expresse your self.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Madam if you want breath, let me help you out.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: I prethee do, do.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: My Lord, the report is, that Mercury coming late into this Country, in this very place, left a Coronet with this inscription, that the best of the five should have it, which the Senses thinking to belong unto them—

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Challenge each other, and are now in arms, and 't like your Lordship.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: I protest it likes not me.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Their battels are not far hence ready rang'd.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: O monstrous presumption! what shall we do?

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: My Lord, in your great Grandfathers time, there was I remember such a breach amongst them, therefore my Counsell is, that after his example, by the strength of your authority you convent them before you.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.p: Lingua go presently, command the Senses upon their alleageance to our dread Sovereign Queen Psyche, to dismisse their companies, and personally to appear before me without any pretence of excuse.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: I go my Lord.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: But hear you Madam, I pray you let your Page tongue walk with us a little, till you return again.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Hot youths I protest, saw you those warlike preparations?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.l: Lately my Lords, I spide into the Army,
But oh, 'tis farre beyond my reach of wit.
Or strength of utterance to describe their forces.

sp.speaker: COM. SENS.
sp.p: Go to, speak what thou canst.

sp.speaker: MEND
sp.l: Upon the right hand of a spatious Hill,
Proud Visus marshalleth a puissant Army,
Three thousand Eagles strong, whose valiant Captain
Is Joves swift Thunder-bearer, that same Bird,
That hoist up Ganimede from the Trojan plains:
The vant-gard strengthned with a wondrous flight
Of Falcons, Haggards, Hobbies, Terselets,
Lanards and Goshauks, Sparhauks, and Ravenous Birds.
The rereward granted to Anditus charge.
Is stoutly follow'd with an impetuous herd
Of stiff-neckt Buls, and many horn-mad staggs,
Of the best head the Forrest can afford.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: I promise you a fearfull troop of Souldiers

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.l: Right opposite stands Tactus strongly mand,
With three thousand brisled Urchins for his Pikemen;
Four hundred Tortesses for Elephants.
Besides a monstrous troop of ugly spiders,
Within an ambushment he hath comnanded,
Of their own guts to spin a cordage fine,
Whereof t'have fram'd a net (O wondrous work)
That fastned by the Concave of the Moon,
Spreads down it self to th' earths circumference.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: 'Tis very strange, I cannot remember the like Engine at any time.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.l: Nay more my Lord, the masks are made so strong,
That I my self upon them scale the heavens,
And boldly walt about the middle region,
Where in the province of the Meteors,
I saw the cloudy shops of Hail and Rain,
Garners of Snow, and Christals full of dew,
Rivers of burning Arrows, Dens of Dragons,
Huge beams of flames, and Spears like fire brands,
Where I beheld hot Mars and Mercury,
With Rackets made of Sphears, and Balls of Stars,
Playing at Tennis for a Tun of Nectar.
And that vast gaping of the Firmament,
Under the Southern pole is nothing else
But the great hazzard of their Tennis Court,
The Zodiack is the line. The shooting Stars,
Which in an eye bright evening seem'd to fall,
Are nothing but the Balls they lose at Bandy.
Thus having took my pleasure with those sights,
By the same net I went up, I discended.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Wel Sirra to what purpose tends this Stratagem?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: None know directly, but I think it is
T'intrap the Eagles, when the Battails joyn.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Who takes Tactus his part?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: Under the standard of thrice hardy Tactus,
Thrice valiant Gustus leads his war-like Forces,
An endlesse multitude of desperate Apes,
Five hundred Marmosets & long-tail'd Monkees:
All trained to the field, and nimble Gunners.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Imagine there's old moving amongst them; Me thinks a handful of Nuts would turn them out of their Souldiers coats,

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.l: Ramparts of Pasty-crust and forts of Pies,
Entrench'd with dishes full of Custard stuff,
Hath Gustus made; and planted ordinance,
Strange ordinance: Canons of hollow canes,
Whose powder's Rape seed, charged with Turnip shot.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.l: I remember in the Country of Utopia,
They use no other kind of Artillery.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: But what's become of Olfactus?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: He politickly leans to neither part,
But stands betwixt the camps as at receit:
Having great wine his Pioners to entrench them.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: In my foolish imagination Olfactus is very like the Goddesse of victory that never takes any part but the Conquerers.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.l: And in the Woods he placed secretly
Two hundred couple of Hounds and hungry Mastiffs:
And ore his head hover at his command
A cloud of Vultures, which or'e spread the light,
Making a night before the day be done:
But to what end not known but feared of all.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: I conjecture he intends to see them fight, and after the battail to feed his Dogs, Hogs and Vultures upon the murdred carcases.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: My L. I think the fury of their anger wil not be obedient to the Message of Lingua; for otherwise in my conceit they should have been here ere this: with your L. good liking we'l attend upon you to see the field for more certainty. It shall be so; Come Master Register lets walk.

div.head: Act. 3. Scena. 1.
div.stage: ANAMESTES, With a purse in his hand.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p:
Forsooth Oblivio shut the door upon me, I could come no sooner; ha? is he not there? O excellent! Would I were hang'd but I lookt for a found rap on the pate, and that made me before hand to lift up this excuse for a Buckler. I know he's not at Court, for here's his purse, without which warrant there's no comming thither; wherefore now Anamnestes sport thy self a little, while thou art out of the prison of his company. What shall I do? by my troth anatomize his purse in his absence. Plutus send there be Jewels in it, that I may finely geld it of the stones— The best sure
lies in the bottome— pox out, here's nothing but a company of worm-eaten papers; what's this? Memorandum that Master Prodigo owes me four thousand pounds, and that his lands are in pawn for it: Memorandum that I owe; that he owes? 'tis well the old slave hath some care of his credit; to whom owes he I trow this? that I owe Anamnestes? What me? I never lent him any thing; ha, this is good, there's something coming to me more then I look'd for. Come on, what is't? Memorandum that I owe Anamnestes— a breeching; I faith Sir I will ease you of that payment, (He rends the bill) Memorandum that when I was a child, Robusto tript up my heels at foot-ball: what a revengeful dizard's this?

div.head: ACT. 3. SCEN. 2.
div.stage: Mendatio with Cushions under his arms, trips up Anamnestes heels.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: MEND
sp.p: Nothing but lay you upon the Cushion Sir, how so?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Nothing but lay the Cushion upon you Sir?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: What my little Nam? by this foot I am sorry I mistook thee.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: What my little Men? by this hand it grieves me I took thee so right. But Sirra whither with these Cushions?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: To lay them here that the Judges may sit softly, least my Lady Lingua's cause go hard with her.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: They should have been wrought with gold, these will do nothing: But what makes thy Lady with the Judges?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Pish, know'st not? she sueth for the title of a Sense, as well as the rest that bear the name of the Pentarchy.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Will Common sense and my Master leave their affairs to determine that Controversie?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Then thou hearst nothing.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: What should I hear!

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: All the Senses fell out about a Crown faln from Heaven, and pitcht a field for it; but Vicegerent Common-sense hearing of it, took upon him to umpire the contention, in which regard he hath appointed them (their armes dismissed) to appear before him, charging every one to bring as it were in a shew their proper objects, that by them he may determine of their several excellencies.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: When is all this?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: As soon as they can possibly provide,

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: But can he tell which deserves best by their objects?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: No not only; for every sense must describe his Instrument, that is his house where he performs his dayly duty, so that by the Object and the Instrument, my Lord can with great ease discern their place and dignities.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: His Lorship's very wise.

sp.speaker: MEND
sp.p:
Thou shalt hear all anon, fine Master
Phantastes, and thy Master will be here shortly. But how is't my little Rogue? me thinks thou look'st lean upon't?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Alas, how should I do otherwise that lie all night with such a Rawbon'd Skeliton as Memory, and run all day on his Errands! The Churle's grown so old and forgetful, that every hour he's calling Anamnestes remembrance, where art Anamnestes? Then presently something's loft, poor I must run for it; and these words, run Boy, Come Sirra quick, quick, quick, are as familiar with him as the Cough, never out on's mouth.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Alack, alack poor Rogue, I see my fortunes are better. My Lady loves me exceedingly; she's always kissing me, so that (I tell the Nam) Mendacios never from betwixt her lips.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Nor out of Memories mouth; but in a worse sort, always exercising my stumps, and which is more, when he favours best, then I am in the worst taking.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Thus, when we are friends, then must I come and be dandled upon his Palsie-quaking knees, and he'l tell me a long story of his acquaintance with King Priamus and his familiarity with Nestor, and how he plaid at blow-point with Jupiter when he was in his side-coats, and how he went to look Birds-nests with Athon, and where he was at Deucalions flood, and twenty such old wives tales.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: I wonder he being so old can talk so much.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Nature thou know'st (knowing what an unruly Engine the tongue is) hath set teeth round about for watchmen; Now Sir my Master's old age hath caught out all his teeth, and that's the cause it runs so much it liberty.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Philosophical!

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: O but there's one thing stings me to the very heart, to see an ugly, foul, idle, fat, dusty clog-head, called Oblivio preferred before me; dost know him?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Who I? I; But care not for his acquaintance, hang him blockhead, I could never abide him. Thou Remembrance art the only friend that the arms of my friendship shall embrace. Thou hast heard Oportet mendacem esse memorem. But what of Oblivio?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: The very naming of him hath made me forget my self. O, O, O, O, that Rascal is so made of everywhere.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Who Oblivio?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: I, for our Courtiers hug him continually in their ungrateful bosomes, and your smooth-belly, fat-backt, barrel-pauncht, tun-gutted drones are never without him; as for Memory he's a false-hearted fellow, he always deceives them; they respect not him except it be to play a game at Chess, Primero, Saunt, Maw, or such like.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.p:
I cannot think such fellows have to do
with Oblivio since they never got any thing to forget.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Again, these prodigal swaggerers that are so much bound to their Creditors, if they have but one Crosse about them they'l spend it in wine upon Oblivio.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: To what purpose I prethee?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Only in hope he'l wash them in the Lethe of their cares.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Why then no man cares for thee!

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Yes, a company of studious paper-worms and lean Schollers, and niggardly scraping Usurers, and a troop of heart-eating envious persons, and those cancker-stomackt spiteful creatures, that furnish up common place-books with other mens faults. The time hath been in those golden days, when Saturn reigned, that if a man received a benefit of another, I was presently sent for to put him in mind of it; but now in these Iron afternoons, save your friends life, and Oblivio will be more familiar with him then you.

div.head: ACTUS. 3. SCENA. 3.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Phantastes not at Court? is't possible? 'tis the strangest accident that ever was heard off; I had thought the Ladies and Gallants would never lie without him.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Hist, hist, Mendacio, I prethee observe Heuresis; it seems he cannot find his Master that's able to find out all things: and art thou now at a fault, canst not find out thine own Master? no? Ile try one more way. O yes.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: What a Proclamation for him?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: I, I, his nimble head is always full of proclamations.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: O yes.

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: But doth he cry him in the wood?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: O good Sir, and good reason, for every beast hath Phantasie at his pleasure.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: O yes: If any man can tell any tidings of a spruce, neat, apish, nimble, fine, foolish, absurd, humerous, conceited, Phantastick Gallant, with hollow eyes, sharp look, swart complexion, meager face, wearing as many toyes in his apparel, as fooleries in his looks and gesture, let him come forth and certifie me thereof, and he shall have for his reward—

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: I can tell you where he is, what shall he have?

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: A box o'the ear sirra, (snap)

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: How now invention, are you so quick fingred? in faith there's your principle sirra, (snap )and here's the interest ready in my hand (snap) [They fall together by the ears. ]Yea? have you found out scratching? now I remember me.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Do you bite you Rascal?

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, here's the lively picture of this axiome, A quick Invention and a good Memory
can never agree. Fie, fie, fie Heuresis, beat him when he's down?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Prethee lets alone, proud Jack-an-Apes, Ile-

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: What will you do?

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: Untrusse thy points and whip thee, thou paltry— Let me go Mendacio if thou lovest me, shall I put up the—

sp.speaker: MEND.
sp.p: Come, come, come, you shall fight no more in good faith: Heuresis; your Master will catch you anon

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: My Master, where is he?

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p: Ile bring you to him, come away.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: Anamnestes, I scorn that thou shouldst think I go away for fear of any thing thou canst do unto me; here's my hand as soon as thou canst pick the least occasion, put up thy finger, I am for thee.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: When thou dar'st Heuresis, when thou dar'st, Ile be as ready as thy self at any time.

This Heuresis, this invention, is the proudest Jack-an-Apes, the peartest self-conceited Boy that ever breath'd; because forsooth some odd Poet, or some such Phantastique fellows make much on him, there's no no with him; the vile dandi-prat will ore-look the proudest of his acquaintance: but well I remember me, I learnt a trick t'other day, to bring a Boy ore the thigh finely; if he come, in faith Ile tickle him with it.

div.stage: Mendacio comes running back in great haste.

sp.speaker: MEN.
sp.p:
As I am a Rascal Nam, they are all coming,
I see Master Register trudging hither, as fast as his three feet will carry up his four Ages.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Ah you leaden-heel'd Rascal.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Here 'tis Sir, I have it, I have it.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Is this all the haste you make?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: An't like your worship, your Clog-head Oblivio went before me, and foil'd the trail of your foot-steps, that I could hardly undertake the quest of your purse forsooth.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: You might have been here long ere this: Come hither sirra, come hither, what must you go round about? goodly, goodly, you are full of circumstances.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: In truth Sir, I was here before, and missing you, went back into the City, sought you in every Ale-house, Inn, Tavern, Dicing-house, Tennis-court, Stews, and such like places, likely to find your worship in.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Ha? villain, am I a man likely to be found in such places, ha?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: No, no Sir; Sir, but I was told by my Lady Lingua's Page that your Worship was seeking me, therefore I enquired for you in those places where I knew you would ask for me, and it please your worship.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I remember another quarrel sirra, but well, well, I have no leisure.

div.head: ACT. 3. SCENA. 5.
div.stage: Com. Sens. Lingua. Phantastes. Memory. Anamnestes.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Lingua, the Senses by our appointment anon are to present their objects before us; seeing therefore they be not in readinesse, we license you in the mean while, either in your own person, or by your Advocate, to speak what you can for your self.

sp.speaker: LIN.
sp.p: My Lord, if I should bring before your honour all my friends ready to importune you in my behalf, I should have so many Rhetoricians, Logitians, Lawyers, and which is more, so many women to attend me, that this Grove would hardly contain the company; wherefore to avoid the tediousnesse, I will lay the whole cause upon the tip of mine own tongue.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Be as brief as the necessity of our short time requires.

sp.speaker: LIN.
sp.p:
My Lord, though the Imbecillitas of my feeble sex, might draw me back from this Tribunal, with the habenis to wit Timoris, and the Catenis Pudoris; notwithstanding being so fairly led on with the gracious {non-Roman} {non-Roman} {non-Roman} of your justissimae {non-Roman} {non-Roman} {non-Roman}, Especially so aspremente spurd 'con'gli sproni di necessita mia pungente, I Will without the helpe of Orators, commit the totam salutem of my
action to the Volutabilitati {non-Roman} {non-Roman} {non-Roman} which (avecuostre bonne playseur) I will finish with more then Laconicâ brevitate.

sp.speaker: CO. SE.
sp.p: Whats this? here's a Gallemaufry of speech indeed.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I remember about the yeare 1602. many used this skew kind of language. Which in my opinion is not much unlike the man Platony the the Sonne of Lagus, King of Aegypt, brought for a spectacle halfe white halfe blacke.

sp.speaker: CO. SE.
sp.p: I am perswaded these same language-makers have the very quality of cold in their wit, that freezeth all Heterogeneall languages together, congealing English Tynne, Graecian Gold, Romane Latine all In a lumpe.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Or rather in my imagination like you Fantasticall Gulls Apparell, wearing a Spanish Felt, a French Doblet, a Granado Stocking, a Dutch Slop, an Italian Cloak, with a Welch frise Jerkin.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Well, leave your toying, we cannot pluck the least feather from the soft wing of time. Therefore Lingua go on, but in a more formall manner; you know an ingenions Oratiō must neither swell above the Banks with insolent words, nor creepe too shallow in the ford, with vulgar terms, but run equally, smooth, and cheerful, through the clean current of a pure style.

sp.speaker: Ling.
sp.p:
My Lord, this one thing is sufficient to confirm my worth to be equal or better then the senses, whose best operations are nothing till I polish
them with perfection; for their knowledge is only of things present, quickly sublimed with the deaf file of time, whereas the tongue is able to recount things past, and often pronounce things to come, by this means re-edifying such Excellencies as Time and Age do easily depopulate.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: But what profitable service do you undertake for our dread Queen Psyche?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: O how I am ravisht to think how infinitely she hath graced me with her most acceptable service. But above all (which you Master Register may well remember) when her Highnesse taking my mouth for her instrument, with the Bow of my tongue strucke so heavenly a touch upon my teeth, that she charmed the very Tigers asleep, the listning Bears and Lions to couch at her feet, while the Hills leaped, and the Woods danced to the sweet harmony of her most Angelical accents.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I remember it very well. Orpheus played upon the Harp, while she sang, about some four years after the contention betwixt Apollo and Pan, and a little before the excoriation of Marsyas.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: By the same token the River Alpheus, at that time pursuing his beloved Arethusa, dischanel'd himself of his former course to be partaker of their admirable confort, and the musick being ended, thrust himself head long into earth, the next way to follow his amorous Chase; if you go to Arcadia, you shall see his coming up again.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Forward Lingua with your reason.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: How oft hath her Excellency imployded me as Embassador in her most urgent affairs to forreign King and Emperors! I may say to the Gods themselves! How many bloudlesse Battails have my perswasions attained, when the senses forces have been vanquished. How many Rebels have I reclaimed when her sacred authority was little regarded? her Laws (without exprobation be it spoken) had been altogether unpublished, her will unperformed, her illustrious deeds unrenouned, had not the silver sound of my trumpet filled the whole circuit of the universe with her deserved fame. Her Cities would dissolve, traffique would decay, friendships be broken, were not my speech the knot. Mercury and Mastique, to bind, defend, and glew them together. What should I say more? I can never speak enough of the unspeakable praise of speech, wherein I can find no other imperfection at all, but that the most exquisite power and excellency of speech cannot sufficiently expresse the exquisite power and excellency of speaking.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Lingua, your service and dignity we confesse to be great; neverthelesse these reasons prove you not to have the nature of a sense.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: By your Lordships favour, I can soon prove that a sense is a faculty, by which our Queen sitting in her privy Chamber hath intelligence of exterior oecurrents. That I am of this nature, I prove thus. The object which I challenge is—

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Stay, stay my Lord, defer I beseech, defer the Judgement.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Who's this that boldly interrupts us thus! hum.

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: My name is Appetitus, Common servant to the Pentarchy of the senses, who understanding that your honour was handling this action of Lingua's, sent me hither thus hastily, most humbly requesting the Bench to consider these Articles they alledge against her, before you proceed to judgement.

sp.speaker: COM. SEN.
sp.p: Hum, here's good stuff, Master Register read them: Appetitus, you may depart, and bid your Mistresse make convenient speed.

sp.speaker: AP.
sp.p: At your Lordships pleasure.

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I Remember that I forgot my spectacles, I left them in the 349. page of Hall's Chronicles, where he tells a great wonder of a multitude of Mice which had almost destroyed the Country, but that there resorted a great mighty flight of Owls, that destroyed them: Anamnestes read these Articles distinctly.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: 1. Ar. Imprimis we accuse Lingua of high treason and sacriledge against the most honourable Common-wealth of letters: for under pretence of profiting the people with translations, she hath most vily prostituted the hard mysteries of unknown Languages to the prophane ears of the vulgar.

sp.speaker: PHAN.
sp.p: This is as much as to make a new Hell in the upper world; for in Hell, they say, Alexander is no better then a Cobler; and now by these translations every Cobler is as familiar with Alexander as he that wrote his life.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: 2. art. Item that she hath wrongfully imprisoned a Lady called Veritas.
3. art. Item that she's a witch, and exerciseth her tongue in exorcismes.
4. art. Item that she's a common whore, and lets everyone lie with her.
