Labour to find the Via lactea
That leads to the Heaven of immortality;
And by the lofty towring of their mind,
Fledgd with the feathers of a learned muse,
They raise themselves unto the highest pitch,
Marrying base earth and heaven in a thought;
But thus I punish their rebellion,
Their industry was never yet rewarded,
Better to sleep then wake and toyl for nothing.

div.head: ACT. 5. SCEN. 17.
div.stage: The five Senses, Lingua, Appetitus, all asleep, and dreaming, Phantastes, Heuresis.

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: So ho Rocwood, so ho Rocwood, Rocwood, your Organ, hay Chanter, Chanter, by Acteons hed-tyre it's a very deep mouth'd dog, a most admirable cry of hounds; look here again, again, there, there, there, ah ware counter.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Do you see the full Moon yonder, and not the man in it? why methinks 'tis too, too evident, I see his dog very plain, and look you, just under his tail is a Thorn-bush of Furs.

sp.speaker: GUS.
sp.p: 'Twill make a fine tooth-pick: that Larks heel there, O do not burn it.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Boy, Heuresis, what think'st thou I think when I think nothing?

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: And it please you Sir, I think you are devising how to answer a man that asks you nothing.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p:
Well gest boy, but yet thou mistook'st it,
for I was thinking of the constancy of women. Appetitus snoars aloud .Beware sirra, take heed, I doubt me there's some wild Boar lodgeth hereabout; how now? methinks these be the Senses, ha? in my conceit the elder brother of death has kist them.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, I am stab'd, I am stab'd, hold your hand, oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: How now? do they talk in the sleep? are they not awake Heuresis?

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: No questionlesse, they be all fast asleep.

sp.speaker: GUS.
sp.p: Eat not too many of those Apples, they be very flative?

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: Foh, foh, beat out this Dog here, foh, was it you Appetitus?

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: In faith it was most sweetly winded, whosoever it was, the warble is very good, and the horn is excellent.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: Put on man, put on, keep your head warm, 'tis cold.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, st, Heuresis, stir not sirra.

sp.speaker: AP.
sp.p: Shut the door, the pot runs over; sirra Cook, that will be a sweet Pasty if you nibble the venison so?

sp.speaker: GUS.
sp.p: Say you so, is a Marrow Pye the Helena of meats? give me't, if I play not Paris hang me; Boy, a clean Trencher?

sp.speaker: AP.
sp.p: Serve up, serve up; this is a fat Rabbet, would I might have the maiden-head of it; come give me the fish there; who hath medled with these maids? ha?

sp.speaker: OLF.
sp.p: Fie, shut your Snuffers closer for shame, 'tis the worst smell that can be.

sp.speaker: TAC
sp.p: O the cramp, the cramp, the cramp, my leg, my leg.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: I must abroad presently, reach me my best Necklace presently.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: Ah Lingua, are you there?

sp.speaker: AUD.
sp.p: Here, take this Rope, and Ile help the leader close with the second Bell: Fie, fie, there is a goodly peal clean spoild.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Ile lay my life that Gentlewoman is painted: well, well, I know it, mark but her nose, do you not see the complection crack out, I must confesse 'tis a good picture.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, fie, I pray you leave, you tickle me so, oh, ah, ha, ha, take away your hands, I cannot endure, ah, you tickle me, ah, ha, ha, ha, ah.

sp.speaker: VIS.
sp.p: Hai, rett, rett, rett, now bird now— look about that bush, she trust her thereabout,— here she is, ware wing Cater, ware wing, avaunt.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Mum, mum, mum, mum.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: st, sirra take heed you wake her not.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: I know Sir she's fast asleep, for her mouth is shut.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: This 'tis to venture upon such uncertainties, to lose so rich a Crown to no end, well, well.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, we shall hear anon where she lost her maiden-head, st, boy, my Lord Vicegerent, and Master Register are hard by, run quickly,
tell them of this accident, wish them come softly.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Mendacio, never talk farther, I doubt 'tis past recovery, and my Robe likewise, I shall never have them again, well, well.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: How? her Crown, and her Robe, never recover them? hum, wast not said to be left by Memory? ha? I conjecture here's some knavery— fast lockt with sleep, in good faith. Was that Crown and Garment yours Lingua?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: I marry were they, and that some body hath felt, and shall feel more, if I live.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: O strange; she answers in her sleep to my question; but how come the Senses to strive for it?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Why, I laid upon purpose in their way, that they might fall together by the ears.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: What a strange thing is this?

div.head: ACT. 5. SCEN. 18.
div.stage: The Senses, Appetitus & Lingua a sleep. Phantastes, Communis Sensus, Memoria, Anamnestes.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: st, my Lord, softly, softly, here's the notablest piece of treason discovered, how say you Lingua set all the Senses at odds, she hath confest it to me in her sleep.

sp.speaker: CHM S.
sp.p: Ist possible Master Register! did you ever know any talk in their sleep?

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: I remember my Lord many have done so very oft, but women are troubled, especially with this talking disease, many of them have I heard answer in their dreams, and tell what they did all day awake.

sp.speaker: ANAM.
sp.p: By the same token, there was a wanton maid, that being askt by her Mother, what such a one did with her so late one night in such a room, she presently said, that—

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: Peace you vild rake hell, is such a jest fit for this company, no more I say sirra.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: My Lord will you believe your own ears, you shall hear her answer me, as directly and truly as may be. Lingua, what did you with the Crown and Garments.

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: Ile tell thee Mendacio.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.p: She thinks Mendacio speaks to her, mark now, mark how truly she will answer: what say you Madam?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p: I say Phantastes is a foolish transparent gull: a meer fanatick nupson in my imagination not worthy to sit as a Judges assistant.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, how truly and directly she answers.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: Faw, faw, she dreams now, she knows not what she saies, Ile trie her once again: Madame? what remedy can you have for your great losses?

sp.speaker: LING.
sp.p:
O are you come Acrasia? welcome, welcome, boy reach a Cushion sit down good Acrasia: I am so beholding to you, your potion
wrought exceedingly, the senses were so mad, did not you see how they raged about the woods?

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Hum, Acrasia? is Acrasia her confederate? my life that Witch hath wrought some villany,—
sp.stage: Lingua viseth in her sleep, and walketh.
sp.p: How's this? is she a sleep? have you seen one walk thus before?

sp.speaker: MEM.
sp.p: It is a very common thing, I have seen many sick of a Peripatetick disease.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: By the same token my Lord, I knew one that went abroad in his sleep, bent his bow, shot at a Magpie, kild her, fetcht his arrow, came home, lockt the dores, and went to bed again.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: What should be the reason of it?

sp.speaker: MEM
sp.p: I remember Scalliger told me the reason once; as I think thus: The nerves that carrie the moving faculty, from the brains, to the thighs, legs, feet, and armes, are wider far then the other nerves; wherefore they are not so easily stopt with the vapours of sleep, but are night and day ready to perform what fancy shall command them.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: It may be so, but Phantastes enquire more of Acrasia.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: What did you with with the potion Acrasia made you.

sp.speaker: LIN.
sp.p: Gave it to the Senses, and made them as mad as— well, If I cannot recover it— let it go, Ile not leave them thus.

sp.speaker: CON. S.
sp.p: Boy awake the Senses there.

sp.speaker: AN.
sp.p: Hoe, hoe, Auditus, up, up, so hoe, Olfactus have at your nose, up Visus, Gustus, Tactus, up: What can you not feel a pinch? have at you with a pin.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: Oh, you stab me, oh.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Tactus, know you how you came hither?

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.l: No my Lord, not I; this I remember,
We sup't with Gustus, and had wine good store,
Whereof I think I tasted liberally.
Among the rest, we drunk a composition,
Of a most dellicate, and pleasant rellish,
That made our brains, somewhat irregular.

div.head: ACTUS. 4. SCENA. 7.
div.stage: The Senses awake, Lingua, a sleep, Communis Sensus, Memory, Anamnestes, Heuresis drawing Crapula.

sp.speaker: HEU.
sp.p: My Lord, here's a fat rascal was lurking in a bush very suspitiously, his name he saies is Crapula.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Sirrah, speak quickly what you know of these troubles.

sp.speaker: CRA.
sp.p: Nothing my Lord, but that the Senses were mad, and that Somnus at my request laid them a sleep, in hope to recover them.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Why then tis too evident, Acrasia at Lingua's request, bewitcht the Senses, wake her quickly Heuresis.

sp.speaker: LIN.
sp.p: Heigh ho, out alas, aye me, where am I? how came I here? where am I? ah.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Lingua look not so strangely upon the matter, you have confest in your sleep, that with a Crown, and a Robe, you have disturb'd the Senses, using a crafty help to enrage them, can you deny it?

sp.speaker: LIN.
sp.p: Aye mee, most miserable wretch, I beseech your Lordship forgive me.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: No, no, tis a fault unpardonable.

sp.speaker: PHAN.
sp.p: In my conceit Lingua, you should seal up your lips, when you go to bed, these Feminine tongues be so glib.

sp.speaker: COM. S.
sp.p: Visus, Tactus, and the rest, our former sentence concerning you, we confirm as irrevocable, and establish the Crown to you Visus, and the Robe to you Tactus, but as for you Lingua—

sp.speaker: LIN.
sp.p: Let me have mine own, howsoever you determine, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: COM: S.
sp.p:
That may not be, your goods are fallen into our hands, my sentence cannot be recall'd, you may see, those that seek what is not theirs, oftentimes loose what's their own: Therefore Lingua granting you your life, I commit you to close Prison, in Gustus his house, and charge
you Gustus, to keep her under the custody of two strong dores, and every day till she come to 80. years of age, see she be well guarded with 30. tall watchmen, without whose license she shall by no means wag abroad; nevertheless use her Lady-like, according to her estate.

sp.speaker: PHAN.
sp.p: I pray you my Lord ad this to the judgement, that whensoever she obtaineth license to walk abroad, in token the Tongue was the cause of her offence, let her wear a velvet hood, made just in the fashion of a great Tongue, in my conceit 'tis a very pritty Embleme of a Woman.

sp.speaker: TAC.
sp.p: My Lord, she hath a vild boy to her Page, a chief agent in this Treason, his name's Mendacio.

sp.speaker: CON. S.
sp.p: Ha? well, I will inflict this punishment on him for this time, let him be soundly whipt, and ever after though he shall strengthen his speeches with the sinews of Truth, yet none shall believe him.

sp.speaker: PHA.
sp.p: In my imagination my Lord, the Day is dead to the great toe, and in my conceit it growes dark, by which I conjecture it will be cold; and therefore in my fancy, and opinion, 'tis best to repair to our Lodgings.

div.head: ACT. 5. SCEN. 20.
div.stage: Anamnestes., Appetitus a sleep in a corner.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: What's this? a fellow whispering so closely with the Earth? so ho, so ho: Appetitus? faith now I think Morpheus himself hath been here, up with a pox to you, up you luske, I have such news to tell thee sirra: all the Senses are well, and Lingua is proved guilty, up, up, up, I never knew him so fast a sleep in my life.
Nay then have at you a fresh, (tiff, toff, tiff, toff.)

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Jog me once again, and Ile throw this whole messe of pottage in your face, cannot one stand quiet at the dresser for you?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I think it's impossible for him to sleep longer then he dreams of his victuals. What Appetitus, up quickly, quickly up, Appetitus, quickly sirra, (toff, toff, toff, toff.)

sp.speaker: APP.
sp.p: Ile come presently, but I hope youle stay till they be roasted, will you eat them raw?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: Roasted? ha, ha, ha, ha, up, up, away.

sp.speaker: APP,
sp.p: Reach the sauce quickly, here's no Sugar, whaw, wam, oh, oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.p: What never wake? (Tiff, toff, tiff, toff,) wilt never be? Then I must trie another way I see.

div.head: Epilogus.
div.l: JƲdicious Friends, it is so late at night,
I cannot waken hungry Appetite:
Then since the cloase upon his rising stands,
Let me obtain this at your courteous hands,
Trie if the friendly opportunity,
Of your good will and gracious Plauditie,
With the thrice welcome murmure it shal keep
Can beg this prisoner from the hands of sleep.
div.stage: Upon the Plaudite Appetitus awakes, and runs in after Anamnestes
